title: Importance of Blood Glucose in Metabolic Health
content: Blood glucose matters significantly with respect to metabolic health and longevity. It is important to pay close attention to metrics like average blood glucose, glucose variability, and peak glucose numbers. Traditional lab testing and metrics consistently miss important insights that a continuous glucose monitor (CGM) can provide. Even nondiabetics are encouraged to utilize a CGM.

title: Limitations of Traditional Blood Tests
content: Traditional blood tests and metrics for determining metabolic health have limitations. For instance, fasting glucose and HbA1c measurements can be misleading. Type 2 diabetes is defined as having a hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) concentration greater than 6.5% which corresponds to an average glucose of approximately 130 milligrams per deciliter. However, this can be misleading in both directions due to factors such as the lifespan of red blood cells and blood loss.

title: Advantages of Continuous Glucose Monitor
content: A continuous glucose monitor (CGM) provides superior insights. It measures glucose continuously, providing data every five minutes in a 24 hour fashion. It can provide reports on average glucose over various periods along with the standard deviation and more. It measures in the interstitial fluid, imputing what the glucose level is in the blood without actually having to sample the blood. CGM actually gives you average blood glucose and you can reverse engineer and impute at A1c, which is much more interesting because you’re directly measuring the variable of interest.

title: Future of Medicine and Doctor’s Visits
content: The future of medicine could involve the use of continuous glucose monitors (CGMs) for patients prior to their first doctor's visit. The data from the CGM would be analyzed by the doctor, providing a detailed look at the patient's glucose levels over a period of time. This could replace the need for an A1c or fasting glucose test. Similarly, some doctors are already using home blood pressure monitors for their patients. However, wearable technology for blood pressure monitoring is still not ready for widespread use.

title: Importance of Glucose Metrics
content: For non-diabetic individuals, lower average blood glucose is better. Minimizing glucose variability and glucose peaks is also important. These metrics can be measured using a CGM. For example, two people may have an average glucose of 100 milligrams per deciliter, but if one has a standard deviation of 10 milligrams per deciliter and the other has a standard deviation of 20, the person with the lower standard deviation is better off.

title: Average Blood Glucose and Mortality
content: Lower average blood glucose is associated with lower mortality rates. This is supported by observational data, although it is difficult to conduct a randomized experiment to confirm this. Outcomes that are considered include all cause mortality, cardiovascular disease and mortality, cancer, cognitive decline and dementia, frailty, and susceptibility to respiratory viruses. A 2011 prospective study found a continuous increase in the associated risk for death throughout a broad range of HbA1c values in nearly 20,000 nondiabetic participants.

title: Glucose and Disease Specific Data
content: The 2011 study also looked at disease specific data, including cardiovascular death and cancer related death. There was a continuous increase in the rate of death in each group as average glucose levels increased. The adjusted hazard ratios showed a 21% increase, a 39% increase, and a 61% associated increase in the risk of cardiovascular death as HbA1c values increased.

title: Japanese Study on Glucose and Mortality
content: A 2013 prospective study in Japan with more than 7,000 participants found similar results. The study followed crude and adjusted mortality from all-causes and cardiovascular disease over a 15-year period. The results showed a similar division in mortality rates based on HbA1c values.

title: Diabetes Treatment and Mortality Rates
content: 2,300 people were being treated for diabetes. The reference range in this case was less than 5% HbA1c. If you look at the mortality rates, you see this continuous increase as you move up the line with the HbA1c. The same thing with cardiovascular disease mortality, although the associated increases in risk are a little bit larger, particularly for the 6. to 6.4% groups. Even when you adjust for confounding variables, you really start to see a rise in mortality with rising blood glucose. For all cause mortality, each increase in hemoglobin A1c accounts for a 20% increase in adjusted mortality and a 32% increase in cardiovascular mortality.

title: Glucose Variability
content: Glucose variability means how much it is rising, falling, et cetera. It's very hard to measure this. They looked at fasting insulin almost as a proxy for altered glucose metabolism. They looked at some of the studies on not only fasting insulin but the HOMA-IR. One of the ways that they would look at glucose variability where they looked at what’s called visit-to-visit variability.

title: HOMA-IR
content: HOMA-IR is a very simple formula—fasting glucose multiplied by fasting insulin divided by 405. Most labs consider a HOMA-IR below 2.0 to be normal, but it is better to see below 1.0.

title: Glucose Variability Study
content: A 2019 study divided people into quartiles based on glucose variability. The study found that the second quartile didn’t have a statistically significant increase in mortality risk but the third and fourth quartiles did right across the board. And it’s not trivial, it’s a doubling of risk.

title: Oral Glucose Tolerance Test
content: A 2018 study used an oral glucose tolerance test on 60 participants, nondiabetic. The study found that “severe glucose variability” was present in 25% of normal glycemic individuals. They also noted that glucose levels reaching pre diabetic ranges happened 15% of the time.

title: Postprandial Dips in Blood Glucose
content: A recent publication looked at CGM and studied the extent to which the postprandial glucose dip was predictive of appetite. They found that the actual dips in your blood glucose were a better predictor of subsequent hunger and energy intake than peak glucose and glucose area under the curve.

title: Glucose Dip and Hunger
content: After a two to three hour period, the glucose dip actually predicted the subsequent amount of food that they ate after that period than the participant’s self reported hunger level. The person who’s going to have the greatest dip probably has a few things going on: They probably had the greatest peak, which led to the greatest amount of insulin production, which then led to the great dip. That speaks to the underlying challenge that person has with fuel partitioning, which speaks to the underlying metabolic dysregulation.

title: Glycemic Responses to Standardized Breakfasts
content: The OGTT is the standard one so they had 75 grams of carbohydrates, all of it in the form of sugar. But when you look at the high carb meal, it’s not that much higher in carbohydrates at about 96 grams of carbohydrates, of which 55 is sugar. That means they’re all starting out just below 100 (averaging probably 90 to 95 milligrams per glucose at start) But they’re peaking sort of between 30 and 60 minutes at nearly nine millimole—that’s about 175 milligrams per deciliter. That would be considered an unacceptable peak by any stretch of the imagination in my book. We never want to see you above 140.

title: Suppression of Fatty Acids and Hunger
content: Exploring the idea that the suppression of fatty acids is actually causing hunger rather than a low blood glucose. They wonder whether it’s the low glucose per se, or if the low glucose might be a proxy for suppression of free fatty acids or lipolysis, which can also be a fuel that you can utilize. In the 2021 paper, they were also just looking at fasting glucose. One of the issues too is whether higher glucose itself necessarily suppresses appetite.

title: Insulin and Lipolysis
content: This shows the effective concentration of insulin to inhibit lipolysis, to drive glucose uptake in the muscle, and then to inhibit gluconeogenesis. For fasting insulin level — the median level is 46 and they’re showing you the 75th percentile within the box there. You do not need to see a big increase in insulin to start to completely inhibit lipolysis, which is the process by which the fat cells stop liberating fat (i.e., they stop letting triglycerides in the form of free fatty acids out of the fat cell).

title: Peak Glucose and Frequency
content: The goal with peak glucose: Lower peaks and fewer peak glucose levels. Over the course of the week, look at how many times you hit a peak glucose. Also pays attention to what the peak number actually is. For instance, let’s say the first threshold of 140 and the patient averaged 10 times a week of going over 140. The first goal would be — Can we reduce that to less than 10? Can we get you down to three times over 140 per week? Once the patient gets to the point where they’re not really going over 140 often, lower the threshold to 130.

title: Impact of Glucose Levels on Health
content: If you’re eating one meal per day that causes an enormous spike in glucose, you are transiently inducing endothelial dysfunction. This is associated with higher carotid intimal thickening which is a harbinger of cerebral vascular disease. It’s very difficult to imagine that that same effect is not also causing coronary atherosclerosis along with carotid atherosclerosis. There are also some prospective studies too where they would look at elevated postprandial glucose and they would try to actually control for fasting glucose. There were some independent associations too with all cause mortality, cardiovascular disease mortality, cancer mortality, frailty.

title: Study on Postprandial Glucose and Mortality
content: A 2009 study out of Taiwan with more than 15,000 nondiabetics found that for cardiovascular and all cause death, a continuous increase in two hour postprandial glucose was associated with a 26% increase in cardiovascular death and a 10% increase in all cause death. When they compared the highest glucose levels to the reference, they saw an associated 98% increase in cardiovascular death risk and a 58% increase in all cause mortality.

title: Metabolic Syndrome and Glucose Dysregulation
content: When you try to control for some of these things, a lot of these things come in packages and they’re looking at a lot of the factors for metabolic syndrome. When you control for somebody who has elevated glucose or they have glucose dysregulation after a two hour meal, it’s very difficult to get a complete picture of what’s going on in the individual because that person will often have i) lower HDL cholesterol, ii) higher triglycerides, iii) higher blood pressure, and iv) higher waist circumference.

title: Rodent Models and Impact of Peak Glucose Levels
content: Acarbose and Canagliflozin have been studied by the Interventions Testing Program (ITP). Acarbose is a drug that is often used in people with type 2 diabetes and it reduces the rate of digestion of carbs (it limits postprandial hyperglycemia). So glucose peaks are basically blunted because acarbose inhibits an enzyme that breaks down starch in the intestine. Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor (inhibits glucose reuptake in the kidneys) and the net effect of this is similar to acarbose in that you lower glucose.

title: Importance of Continuous Glucose Monitoring
content: Continuous Glucose Monitoring (CGM) is not just a tool for people with diabetes, it’s a tool for anybody who’s interested in improving their health because it gives you the best real world insight into these three metrics: What’s your average blood glucose? How much does it vary? How high are the peaks and how often do you have them?
